message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The hyperechoic mass seen on ultrasonography is consistent with a liver adenoma, which can be at risk for spontaneous rupture and intraperitoneal hemorrhage if a biopsy is done. Biopsy is not typically associated with risk of biliary peritonitis, bacteremia, or metastatic spread.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and ultrasound findings suggest a liver hemangioma. A biopsy of this vascular lesion can cause intraperitoneal hemorrhage due to the high vascularity of the lesion. Biliary peritonitis or bacteremia are unlikely to occur from a biopsy of a liver hemangioma. Metastases do not occur from a benign liver hemangioma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The ultrasonography findings are most consistent with a hepatic adenoma, which has a risk of intraperitoneal hemorrhage with biopsy or rupture. Biliary peritonitis and bacteremia are less likely complications. Metastatic spread is not a concern as hepatic adenomas are benign.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the ultrasound findings suggests that the patient has a liver hemangioma, which is a benign tumor of blood vessels. A biopsy of the lesion carries the risk of intraperitoneal hemorrhage due to the rich vascularity of the tumor. The other options are not likely to be complications of a liver biopsy in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and imaging findings suggest a liver hemangioma, which is a benign tumor made up of abnormal blood vessels. Biopsy carries a risk of intraperitoneal hemorrhage due to the highly vascular nature of the tumor. Biliary peritonitis, bacteremia, and metastatic spread are not known complications of a liver hemangioma biopsy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and the imaging suggest a liver tumor, which can lead to intraperitoneal hemorrhage if a biopsy is performed. Biliary peritonitis, bacteremia, and metastatic spread are not common complications of liver biopsies.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The ultrasonography suggests the patient has a liver adenoma, which can rupture and cause intraperitoneal hemorrhage if a biopsy is performed. Biliary peritonitis, bacteremia, and metastatic spread are not common complications of liver biopsy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The well-demarcated, homogeneous, hyperechoic mass surrounded by normal liver tissue on ultrasonography suggests that the patient has a benign liver tumor such as a hepatic adenoma. Biopsy of these tumors may lead to intraperitoneal hemorrhage, especially in larger tumors that are closer to the surface. Complications such as biliary peritonitis or bacteremia are less likely with a biopsy of a liver tumor. Metastatic spread would not be a concern with a benign tumor.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The hyperechoic mass described on ultrasound is suggestive of a benign liver adenoma. Biopsy of such a mass can cause intraperitoneal hemorrhage due to the vascular nature of the lesion. Biliary peritonitis is a rare complication of liver biopsy, while bacteremia and metastatic spread are not typical complications.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's presentation and imaging findings suggest a possible hepatic adenoma, which can be vascular and put the patient at risk for intraperitoneal hemorrhage if a biopsy is performed. Biliary peritonitis, bacteremia, and metastatic spread are not common complications of liver biopsy.
